results.abstract: NASA space shuttle Endeavour closes in on International Space Station, and astronauts who have been living on station for month deal with traffic jam; two Russian Progress supply craft are already docked to complex; to make room for Endeavour, Russian ground controllers undock one Progress and park it in orbit mile beneath station; Endeavour's mission is to hang solar-power panels on space station; diagrams (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Nearing Space Station And Causing A Traffic Jam

results.snippet: As the NASA space shuttle Endeavour closed in on the International Space Station today, the astronauts who have been living on the station for a month dealt with their first traffic jam.    Two Russian Progress supply craft were already docked to the...
results.lead_paragraph: As the NASA space shuttle Endeavour closed in on the International Space Station today, the astronauts who have been living on the station for a month dealt with their first traffic jam. Two Russian Progress supply craft were already docked to the $60 billion complex, so to make room for the shuttle, Russian ground controllers undocked one Progress and parked it in orbit about a mile beneath the station.

headline.main: Space Station Gets Its Wings, But Only One Is Deployed

results.snippet: The new International Space Station became bigger and potentially more powerful today with the addition of the largest set of solar-power wings ever put on a spacecraft. However, only one of the two wings was deployed as planned while engineers...
results.lead_paragraph: The new International Space Station became bigger and potentially more powerful today with the addition of the largest set of solar-power wings ever put on a spacecraft. However, only one of the two wings was deployed as planned while engineers awaited answers to a series of small problems. Two spacewalking astronauts, Joseph R. Tanner and Carlos I. Noriega, assisted in attaching a 17-ton power assembly after it was lifted by a robot arm from the payload bay of the space shuttle Endeavour. Operating the arm from within the shuttle, a Canadian astronaut, Dr. Marc Garneau, moved the $600 million power unit to the top of the station, where the waiting spacewalkers helped guide it to its final position.

results.abstract: Spacesuits worn by astronauts during Apollo Moon landings and other early space flights are deteriorating; experts say this tough apparel, made of multiple layers of natural and synthetic materials, is slowly consuming itself as some of components break down and corrode adjacent components; National Air and Space Museum, which posseses more than 250 spacesuits, is coordinating program to find ways to protect garments from further damage; photos (M)

headline.main: Mighty Moon Suits Are Falling Apart

results.snippet: For people awake and aware during the Apollo Moon landings, the most unforgettable images sent to Earth were of astronauts in their ghostly white spacesuits framed by the gray landscape of another world.    Shielded in the suits from the Moon's harsh...
results.lead_paragraph: For people awake and aware during the Apollo Moon landings, the most unforgettable images sent to Earth were of astronauts in their ghostly white spacesuits framed by the gray landscape of another world. Shielded in the suits from the Moon's harsh environment, the men skipped across the dusty terrain, scooted about in wire-wheeled buggies, picked up piles of rocks and even swatted golf balls over the horizon.

results.abstract: Astronauts aboard space shuttle Endeavour complete addition of major upgrade in power for International Space Station, extending second solar power wing after overcome some problems (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Finish Adding Solar Wing To Station

results.snippet: Working with deliberate starts and stops, astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour today completed the addition of a major upgrade in power for the International Space Station by extending a second solar power wing over the spacecraft.    After...
results.lead_paragraph: Working with deliberate starts and stops, astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour today completed the addition of a major upgrade in power for the International Space Station by extending a second solar power wing over the spacecraft. After difficulties on Sunday with the deployment of the right power wing, which left it less taut than expected when fully extended, National Aeronautics and Space Administration controllers spent today working out a new procedure for reeling out the left wing, which appeared to succeed.

results.abstract: Front Row column; Gucci announces that it will acquire 51 percent of Alexander McQueen's business featuring eccentric ready-to-wear fashions; photo (M)

headline.main: Front Row; Gucci secures a deal with Alexander McQueen Cookies are more gratifying than shoes A Bergdorf Goodman documentary.

results.snippet: Gucci Adds Alexander McQueen      A few months ago, the designer Tom Ford introduced his boss, Domenico De Sole, the chief executive of the Gucci Group, to another talented designer in his 30's. He thought Mr. De Sole should get to know him. The...
results.lead_paragraph: Gucci Adds Alexander McQueen A few months ago, the designer Tom Ford introduced his boss, Domenico De Sole, the chief executive of the Gucci Group, to another talented designer in his 30's. He thought Mr. De Sole should get to know him. The designer was Alexander McQueen, and after extensive talks with Mr. De Sole, Gucci announced yesterday that it would acquire 51 percent of Mr. McQueen's business. It is a business that is hardly a cash cow. Sales of Mr. McQueen's eccentric ready-to-wear -- his recent collection featured a full-length skirt made of mussel shells -- are ''not large,'' Mr. De Sole admitted. ''We believe the potential is there,'' he said. Mr. McQueen now has one store in London; Mr. De Sole said he planned to open more in the obvious fashion capitals -- New York, Paris and Milan.

results.abstract: Robert Ballard is using submersible vehicles to take video images of floor of Pearl Harbor, where evidence of Japanese sneak attack on US fleet in 1941 lies scattered; images are posted on National Geographic Society Web site; photo (M)

headline.main: Exploring the Depths That Will Live in Infamy

results.snippet: The waters around Pearl Harbor are littered with ships and planes that were destroyed during the Japanese attack on the Hawaiian island of Oahu on Dec. 7, 1941.    Robert Ballard, the undersea exporer who discovered the Titanic and the Yorktown, an...
results.lead_paragraph: The waters around Pearl Harbor are littered with ships and planes that were destroyed during the Japanese attack on the Hawaiian island of Oahu on Dec. 7, 1941. Robert Ballard, the undersea exporer who discovered the Titanic and the Yorktown, an aircraft carrier sunk during the Battle of Midway, is using submersible vehicles to see what is lying 1,200 feet below Pearl Harbor.

results.abstract: Joan Jett discusses her bad-girl-of-rock reputation and role in Rocky Horror Show at Circle in the Square Theater; photo (Public Lives column) (S)

headline.main: A Determined Rocker Takes On Broadway

results.snippet: STRIPPED down to the bare essentials -- tattoos and a tiger-stripe bikini thong -- between costume changes for a publicity shoot at the Circle in the Square Theater, Joan M. Jett seems less formidable than the sneering, snarling bad-girl-of-rock...
results.lead_paragraph: STRIPPED down to the bare essentials -- tattoos and a tiger-stripe bikini thong -- between costume changes for a publicity shoot at the Circle in the Square Theater, Joan M. Jett seems less formidable than the sneering, snarling bad-girl-of-rock reputation that preceded her to Broadway. Her speaking voice is a tired contralto, and beneath a rainbow of lid-to-brow stage makeup, her left eye is flecked with blood: she spent the morning at the hospital having a piece of theater grit extracted by her favorite physician, the one she entrusts with her vocal cords. But Ms. Jett's ''Rocky Horror Show'' understudy won't inherit her dual roles as Columbia and Usherette, or that solo wail on guitar in ''The Time Warp,'' tonight. No one has ever called Ms. Jett a quitter. When 23 record companies declined to produce her first album, dismissing a leather-wrapped, guitar-slinging teenage girl as offensively unmarketable, she did it herself.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Berlin-Cinema.'' Tomorrow at 2 p.m., Walter Ruttman's ''Berlin, Symphony of a City'' (1927), a restored print with live...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Berlin-Cinema.'' Tomorrow at 2 p.m., Walter Ruttman's ''Berlin, Symphony of a City'' (1927), a restored print with live music by Donald Sosin. Tomorrow at 4 p.m. and Sunday at 2 and 4:30 p.m., Samira Gloor-Fadel's documentary, ''Berlin-Cinema (Titre Provisoire),'' narrated by Wim Wenders and Jean-Luc Godard. ''Repertory Nights,'' a program tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., featuring Mr. Wenders's ''Wings of Desire'' (1987). Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

results.abstract: Saudi Arabia faces array of challenges as defacto leader Crown Prince Abdullah begins to take cautious steps to open insular society to increased foreign investment, trade and tourism without provoking political and social unrest; photo (M)

headline.main: With Trepidation, Saudi Arabia Meets the World

results.snippet: Prince Sultan bin Salman is a familiar face in Saudi Arabia. A strapping former Air Force pilot, he flew as an astronaut on an American space shuttle 15 years ago, is a grandson of the nation's founder, the son of a well-known governor, and now the...
results.lead_paragraph: Prince Sultan bin Salman is a familiar face in Saudi Arabia. A strapping former Air Force pilot, he flew as an astronaut on an American space shuttle 15 years ago, is a grandson of the nation's founder, the son of a well-known governor, and now the nation's tourism chief. But on a recent trip to a village market near Taif he saw firsthand what it might be like to arrive a stranger in the conservative and provincial kingdom.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''The Films of Jacques Tati.'' Tomorrow at 2, 4:15 and 6:30 p.m., Tati's ''Playtime'' (1968), a restored print with nearly...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''The Films of Jacques Tati.'' Tomorrow at 2, 4:15 and 6:30 p.m., Tati's ''Playtime'' (1968), a restored print with nearly 20 minutes of film that was cut from the original United States release. Sunday at 2 p.m., Tati's short film ''L'Ecole des Facteurs'' (1947), followed by his ''Jour de Fete'' (1948). Sunday at 4:15 p.m., Rene Clement's short film ''Soigne Ton Gauche'' (1936), followed by Tati's ''Mr. Hulot's Holiday'' (''Les Vacances de Monsieur Hulot'') (1953). ''Repertory Nights,'' a program Sunday at 6:30 p.m., featuring Jean Vigo's ''L'Atalante'' (1934). Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,''...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, and ''Festival of Trees,'' Staten Island students decorating trees for the museum's annual competition. Both through Dec. 30. Closed Sunday and Dec. 31. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

results.abstract: Vision of the future presented in 2001: A Space Odyssey, 1968 film by Stanley Kubrick and Arthur C Clarke, discussed in light of plans to release new version of film, with digital sound and light, next year; photo (M)

headline.main: On the Eve of 2001, the Future Is Not Quite What It Used to Be

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: TWO THOUSAND ONE: A SPACE ODYSSEY (MOVIE)

results.snippet: Prediction is very hard, the quantum physicist Niels Bohr once said, especially regarding the future, but that is exactly the job and the predicament of the science fiction writer. Next week, the future arrives for one of the most famous prophecies...
results.lead_paragraph: Prediction is very hard, the quantum physicist Niels Bohr once said, especially regarding the future, but that is exactly the job and the predicament of the science fiction writer. Next week, the future arrives for one of the most famous prophecies of all time, ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' Stanley Kubrick, who directed and produced the movie, died in 1999, but his partner Arthur C. Clarke, who wrote the book on which he and Mr. Kubrick based the screenplay, is alive and well in Sri Lanka and will be around for the release of a new version of ''2001'' with digital light and sound next year, as well as comparisons of the future then and now.

results.snippet: Holiday Shopping Season Could Be Worst in Decade  Despite widespread markdowns and a burst of last minute buying, this year's holiday shopping season is shaping up as among the worst in a decade, industry analysts said.    Consumers were treated to...
results.lead_paragraph: Holiday Shopping Season Could Be Worst in Decade Despite widespread markdowns and a burst of last minute buying, this year's holiday shopping season is shaping up as among the worst in a decade, industry analysts said. Consumers were treated to deep and widespread price reductions during the holiday season, and almost everywhere they reacted with restraint. Several of the nation's largest chains acknowledged that December sales were going to be lower than they had predicted at the beginning of the season. [Page A1.]

results.abstract: Annie Gottlieb Op-Ed article reports comeback for people with gray in their hair, especially since downturn in Internet economy has chastened young hotshots (M)

headline.main: At Last, We Elders Get Some Respect

results.snippet: Now that the election fracas is behind us, those of us with gray hair should be the ones to lead our riven country's healing process, former Senator Alan Simpson has suggested. Though he was referring specifically to fellow elder statesmen like Bob...
results.lead_paragraph: Now that the election fracas is behind us, those of us with gray hair should be the ones to lead our riven country's healing process, former Senator Alan Simpson has suggested. Though he was referring specifically to fellow elder statesmen like Bob Dole and Howard Baker, I bet I'm not the only one with gray hair who's silently cheering. Having been a little girl in the feminine-mystique 50's, I'm still thrilled every time I see a woman senator, astronaut, surgeon, soldier or firefighter. Having entered my 50's in the brutally youth-besotted 90's, I'm now even more thrilled every time I see a frankly ''mature'' person -- as the euphemism goes -- claim our culture's center stage.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has opened, with the same hours as the museum. Tomorrow...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has opened, with the same hours as the museum. Tomorrow from noon to 5 p.m., Kwaanza celebrations, including performances, visual and performing arts workshops and a film festival. The Hall of Ocean Life will be transformed to an African village with a marketplace. The annual origami tree is on display during the holidays. Museum admission: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children 2 to 12; under 2, free. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' Tickets: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children under 12. In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200. Visitors can buy a First Night New York City 2001 Button, $10 for adults, $5 for children (2 to 12), for free admission into the museum Sunday. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: (212) 676-2000 or www.nycmillennium.org.
